What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course deepened my knowledge of Ancient Greek grammar and vocabulary, but also introduced me to the basics of poetry in great depth. So, we learned a lot more than just Greek, which was great.
In this class I improved my understanding of the ancient greek language, grammar, and morphology through the lens of Homeric poetry.

This course explored the grammar and dialect of Homeric Greek while reading selected books in the Odyssey. We learned how to read in dactylic hexameter, how to parse difficult words in the Greek, and some of the more complicated structure.
We read two whole books of the Odyssey, and also engaged with some secondary literature and related scholarship, including manuscript reading and translation.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course was very well-planned out and offered lots of opportunities for student feedback, which I appreciated. At the same time, I did feel that the workload of the course was certainly intensive. While there was the opportunity for accommodation, the circumstances of the pandemic had just already made things difficult for me. Other than that, the course was really well taught and was a natural step after GREK 131.

Strengths: manageable homework schedule, dynamic teaching fellow, occasional outside readings, in class presentation of slideshow on shared screen so as to simulate a classroom, intimate class size (very important to be directly participating multiple times in class in order to enhance one's understanding of the language in practice).

Weaknesses: none

This course was excellent! I really enjoyed the coverage of the material especially in reading the selected books of the Odyssey. The pacing of the class was perfect and I really wouldn't change a thing.

This class was overall very strong. The reading pace was fast, and in the beginning we did struggle to keep up with the syllabus, but we eventually improved a lot in speed. Sylva's course design was excellent-- weekly vocabulary lists were super helpful and useful, presentations on certain grammar, meter, etc constructions were useful and very well integrated with the text. I not only gained a lot of knowledge of Homer but I also feel my Greek overall is much better and my skills with close reading. The assessment design was excellent, especially the final.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I enjoyed the frequent use of the share screen to go over passages together, highlighting and annotating where necessary. I found that to be really helpful and it also meant that I wasn't required to try to have my computer open onto several separate windows (as I'd had to do in the past).

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think this course is excellent preparation for better understanding Greek, but also develops certain analytical skills that are broadly applicable. I would certainly recommend it.
Yes! If one is interested in learning about Homeric poetry or the greek language in general, then this is a course for you.
Yes! Anyone interested in reading Homeric Greek should take it! You learn a lot about the dialect and really explore a lot of the aspects of Homeric Scholarship.
Absolutely, especially if Sylva is teaching it. I wasn't the biggest Homer fan, but this class is vital to studying Greek as a whole.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
